citations.narrative:
Multiple APHIS Forms 7006's were missing the name and address of where the puppies were going to. Not recording the
name and address where each dog is going doesn't allow APHIS officials to properly track all the dogs leaving the
licensee's facility. The licensee must record the name and address for every dog that leaves the facility on the APHIS
Form 7006. Correct starting on 6/3/25.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to find the program of veterinary care, exercise, plan, APHIS Forms 7005, and contingency plan.
Not being able to find all the required documents during inspection doesn't allow for APHIS officials to ensure the animals
are being cared for as required and the requirements of the Animal Welfare Act are being met. The licensee must find and
produce all required documents at the next inspection. If the required documents can't be found, then the licensee must
have the attending veterinarian develop a new program of veterinary care and exercise plan. In addition, the licensee
must fill out new APHIS Forms 7005 and contingency plan. Correct by 7/3/25.

Eight puppies born on 1/17/24 were shipped on 3/13/25. They were shipped one day prior to the 8 week minimum age
requirement. Puppies younger than 8 weeks of age are more susceptible to stresses that occur from travelling and being
placed into a new facility. Their immune systems are more susceptible to becoming compromised which could cause
them to become sick and even die. The licensee must not sell and transport any puppies under 8 weeks of age. Correct
starting on 6/3/25.

Rust was observed on multiples fences/gates of enclosures during the inspection. Rust doesn't allow for the enclosures to
be properly sanitized. The fencing/gates of the enclosures must be painted, replaced, or fixed so the surfaces the dogs
come into contact with are rust free. Correct by 7/3/25.

An approximately 2-3 year old female Golden Doodle is being housed individually. The dog is only being let out into the
play yard once a week. I contacted the Attending Veterinarian and was advised that he wants his client to be providing 30
minutes of exercise 5 times a week. The licensee is not meeting that requirement. The dog measured 29 inches in length.
Her enclosure measured 37'' by 36'' for a total amount of 1,332 square inches of space. Based on her length and her not
being provided additional or adequate exercise opportunities (based on what the Attending Veterinarian advised), she
requires 2,450 square inches of space. Her enclosure is short by 1,118 square inches of space.
Not providing a dog regular opportunities to exercise when the dog is being housed individually in an enclosure that is
less than two times the required floor space for that dog doesn't ensure that the dog is getting enough exercise to meet
their physical and mental needs. The licensee must ensure that individually housed dogs are either being provided regular
opportunities to exercise or the dogs must be provided enclosures that are more than two times the required floor space
for each dog. Correct starting on 6/3/25.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Multiple enclosures had an excessive amount of feces buildup within the enclosure. In addition, the flies throughout the
kennel were excessive. It was obvious the enclosures hadn't been cleaned within the past day. When asked, the licensee
stated the enclosures were last cleaned on Saturday, two days prior to the first day of inspection. The buildup of feces can
contribute to the spread of disease and attract flies (as is the case with this inspection). Excreta must be removed from
the primary enclosures daily. Correct starting on 6/3/25.

A complete physical exam of all the adult dogs has not been completed in the past year. Not having the physical exams
completed doesn't ensure that adequate veterinary care is being provided to the dogs. The licensee must have the
Attending Veterinarian conduct annual exams on all the adult dogs. Correct by 7/3/25.

None of the adult dogs are current on their rabies vaccines. In addition, no dogs have been sampled for heartworm or
fecal parasites in the past year. Not vaccinating all adults dogs for rabies and not sampling the adult dogs for parasites
doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from various diseases and parasites. All adult dogs must be vaccinated
for rabies and must be sampled for parasites in accordance with a plan from the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by
7/3/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)(iv) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Multiple APHIS Forms 7006's were missing the name and address of where the puppies were going to. Not recording the 
name and address where each dog is going doesn't allow APHIS officials to properly track all the dogs leaving the 
licensee's facility. The licensee must record the name and address for every dog that leaves the facility on the APHIS 
Form 7006. Correct starting on 6/3/25. 
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee was unable to find the program of veterinary care, exercise, plan, APHIS Forms 7005, and contingency plan. 
Not being able to find all the required documents during inspection doesn't allow for APHIS officials to ensure the animals 
are being cared for as required and the requirements of the Animal Welfare Act are being met. The licensee must find and 
produce all required documents at the next inspection. If the required documents can't be found, then the licensee must 
have the attending veterinarian develop a new program of veterinary care and exercise plan. In addition, the licensee 
must fill out new APHIS Forms 7005 and contingency plan. Correct by 7/3/25. 
2.130 
   
Minimum age requirements. 
Eight puppies born on 1/17/24 were shipped on 3/13/25. They were shipped one day prior to the 8 week minimum age 
requirement. Puppies younger than 8 weeks of age are more susceptible to stresses that occur from travelling and being 
placed into a new facility. Their immune systems are more susceptible to becoming compromised which could cause 
them to become sick and even die. The licensee must not sell and transport any puppies under 8 weeks of age. Correct 
starting on 6/3/25. 
3.6(a)(2)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Rust was observed on multiples fences/gates of enclosures during the inspection. Rust doesn't allow for the enclosures to 
be properly sanitized. The fencing/gates of the enclosures must be painted, replaced, or fixed so the surfaces the dogs 
come into contact with are rust free. Correct by 7/3/25.

3.8(a) 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
An approximately 2-3 year old female Golden Doodle is being housed individually. The dog is only being let out into the 
play yard once a week. I contacted the Attending Veterinarian and was advised that he wants his client to be providing 30 
minutes of exercise 5 times a week. The licensee is not meeting that requirement. The dog measured 29 inches in length. 
Her enclosure measured 37'' by 36'' for a total amount of 1,332 square inches of space. Based on her length and her not 
being provided additional or adequate exercise opportunities (based on what the Attending Veterinarian advised), she 
requires 2,450 square inches of space. Her enclosure is short by 1,118 square inches of space. 
 
Not providing a dog regular opportunities to exercise when the dog is being housed individually in an enclosure that is 
less than two times the required floor space for that dog doesn't ensure that the dog is getting enough exercise to meet 
their physical and mental needs. The licensee must ensure that individually housed dogs are either being provided regular 
opportunities to exercise or the dogs must be provided enclosures that are more than two times the required floor space 
for each dog. Correct starting on 6/3/25. 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Multiple enclosures had an excessive amount of feces buildup within the enclosure. In addition, the flies throughout the 
kennel were excessive. It was obvious the enclosures hadn't been cleaned within the past day. When asked, the licensee 
stated the enclosures were last cleaned on Saturday, two days prior to the first day of inspection. The buildup of feces can 
contribute to the spread of disease and attract flies (as is the case with this inspection). Excreta must be removed from 
the primary enclosures daily. Correct starting on 6/3/25. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
A complete physical exam of all the adult dogs has not been completed in the past year. Not having the physical exams 
completed doesn't ensure that adequate veterinary care is being provided to the dogs. The licensee must have the 
Attending Veterinarian conduct annual exams on all the adult dogs. Correct by 7/3/25. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
None of the adult dogs are current on their rabies vaccines. In addition, no dogs have been sampled for heartworm or 
fecal parasites in the past year. Not vaccinating all adults dogs for rabies and not sampling the adult dogs for parasites 
doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from various diseases and parasites. All adult dogs must be vaccinated 
for rabies and must be sampled for parasites in accordance with a plan from the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 
7/3/25. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.

n
